data.title: state government Archives – Mid
data.text:
Viewpoint: City’s delegation scores wins in Baton Rouge during challenging session

By Danae Columbus, opinion columnist The 2023 legislative session in Baton Rouge ended June 8 with a controversial last-minute budget bill and a package of bills targeting the transgender community. Attempts by Democrats to add rape and incest as exceptions to the state’s near total abortion ban, raise the minimum wage and abolish the death Read More…

Viewpoint: Cantrell-related PAC opposes efforts to realign the recall process

By Danae Columbus, opinion columnist Two like-minded bills that together will fundamentally redefine the recall process for Louisiana elected officials are working their way through the 2023 legislative session in Baton Rouge. Though the new laws, if ultimately approved, will bring Louisiana’s rules in closer alignment with other states, a political action committee associated with Read More…

Who owns the bayou? Dispute over tree raises questions about oversight of Bayou St. John

By Gwen Dilworth, Mid-City Messenger Mathilde Lemann decided last year that planting a tree on Bayou St. John would be a meaningful way to honor her cousin Denise Dalferes, who passed away in 2020 without a proper memorial service. The tree was planted next to Magnolia Bridge with approval from the city — but it Read More…

Rep. Aimee Adatto Freeman celebrates ‘pink tax’ exemption (sponsored)

Freeman’s Law Ending State Tax on Feminine Hygiene Products and Diapers Effective Today. A new law to end the so-called “pink tax” authored by state Rep. Aimee Adatto Freeman, D-New Orleans, became effective Friday (July 1). It provides for a state sales and use tax exemption for feminine hygiene products and diapers for personal use and Read More…

Opposing views of the resurgent BioDistrict presented at forum

By Katherine Hart, Mid-City Messenger A Mid-City Neighborhood Organization forum on the city’s BioDistrict filled the Warren Easton High School cafeteria Monday evening (Feb. 1). And more Mid-City residents watched on Zoom as Andy Kopplin, who chairs the BioDistrict Board of Commissioners, and Jeffrey Schwartz, the city’s economic development director, presented information on new Read More…

LSU tears down McDonogh 11 building after three moves and millions of taxpayer dollars

When the McDonogh 11 building was moved to South Claiborne Avenue and Cleveland in 2014, a state official said that — after two previous relocations — it was the historic building’s final resting place. It turns out, he was right. The 142-year-old building was demolished Wednesday (June 23) morning, the Preservation Resource Center reported on Read More…

New bike lanes planned for Bienville and Ursulines

A few Mid-City and Faubourg St. John streets are getting new bike lanes as part of the city’s Moving New Orleans Bikes project. The project, which operates in tandem with the street repair programs, is designed to accelerate the construction of 75-mile bicycle network. “Now we have a lot of shared lanes in these neighborhoods,” Read More…

Viewpoint: Mail-in ballots are essential for the safety of Louisiana voters

By Danae Columbus, Opinion Columnist Who wants to potentially put themselves or their family members at risk by voting at a poll on upcoming election days? With Louisiana’s presidential primary and other ballot measures now scheduled for July 11, state officials are squabbling over how to hold safe elections during the pandemic and beyond. Newly Read More…

Why restaurants and drive-thru daiquiri shops can sell alcohol to-go as bars remain shuttered

By Sharon Lurye, Mid-City Messenger While some bars in New Orleans hoped they could survive the economic fallout of COVID-19 by selling alcohol to-go, city and state officials have clarified that they must close completely – leading to a peculiar situation where restaurants, breweries and even drive-thru daiquiri shops can sell alcohol to-go, but not Read More…
